text: oh the power structure in Washington is
not individuals it's a system it is uh A
system that um is immune to criticism I
mean the effort uh on the part of people
like Jeff Flake and Tom Coburn to get
rid of uh uh earmarks uh is heroic but
utterly feudal and uh and you know the
bridge to nowhere I mean uh these people
think that they can do whatever they
want to and one of the problems with the
system we have as it exists in my view
is that
um you under the current system you you
have a adverse selection process for who
runs for Congress and there are people
who want to be uh professional
politicians who want to run others lives
who want the power of being a politician
and uh that's why we need term limits
but um it is not some kind of deal where
where Corporate America runs Washington
or uh left-wingers do or right-wingers
do it is just the center of power and it
stays that way and and uh will until
there's some radical change in the way
we uh operate our politics in this
country well the people are there
they're mostly entrepreneurs but uh the
way to do it is to have term limits
because a lot of smart people look at
the uh process of uh of uh getting
elected and uh say you know even if I
did get elected I'm going to have to be
under the control of professional
politicians and my influence is going to
be negligible whereas if you had a
citizen Congress particularly in the
House of Representatives a lot more
people would find that attractive and of
course there'd be a lot more open seats
if you had six-year limits three terms
there'd be a lot of open seats every
election uh and then the other thing is
to get rid of the contribution limits
and then you'd find people uh a friend
of mine Tim Penny was a I think a a
10-year uh congressman from Minnesota
and he was uh going to run for the
Senate from Minnesota after he stepped
down
voluntarily and um Tim um was ahead in
the polls against the Democrats in the
primary and any test against Republicans
in the general election he was going to
win and he dropped out and I I ran into
him and I said Tim why'd you do that he
said you know ad I was looking at 12
months of 8 to 10 hours a day asking
people for
$1,000 and I just didn't want to do that
I didn't want to take that time away
from my family I found it demeaning
whereas if if you know 10 people could
have gone in and say well will each give
you
$250,000 and your campaign is of and
running uh I'm sure he would have run
and we'd have a good guy Tim Penny was
terrific uh in the US Senate uh so I
think the the campaign Finance laws and
the lack of term limits are the problem
that we have in getting better people
running for congress
I think that the large contributions
give people more choices as long as you
know this is Bill Gates candidate well
you can say you know I'm not going to
vote for Bill Gates candidate and or
George soros's candidate and um that's
disclosure but money is a proxy for
information and uh you know uh something
like 80% of Americans don't know the
name of their
congressman and and the the campaign
Finance reformers are constantly saying
the uh there's too much money in
politics well if people don't even know
the name of their Congressman maybe
there's not enough money in politics but
certainly Challengers have an
opportunity when there's money and
there's a big uh vested interest on the
part of incumbents to say you know what
we uh money's corrupting so we're not
going to let any money in it because the
best amount of money for a campaign for
an incumbent is zero zero because the
inc's always going to win and
particularly if you want a citizen
legislator if you want somebody who is
just a successful person a teacher a
doctor a
businessman uh and he has no political
history he has no mailing list uh but
he's a good smart person with good
ethical standards and he wants to run he
has no chance under with these uh
campaign Finance laws so it's a it's
very inhibiting to a a vibrant and
viable
democracy the Constitution of the United
States is nothing but a a series of uh
constraints on untrammeled Democracy I
mean we're not a majoritarian society
we're not set up to be a majoritarian
society um what are there 650 or 700,000
people in each congressional district
the idea that there's only one person
that can represent that district is
ludicrous
um I think it's a it's a it's a
political prophylactic it's a way of
saying you know we're not going to allow
our system be corrupted by people who
are into power now I'm open to no term
limits on the Senate because you can't
gerrymander the Senate to begin with uh
the whole state gets to vote and um and
there's an argument that some people are
pretty wise and they probably should
stay in the Senate but the house of
repres Representatives is supposed to be
representative representative is
supposed to be an adjective not a noun
and um and I think term limits is uh
fully consistent with a libertarian
worldview
